Description: Beads pertaining to a necklace in glazed composition. One bead in the shape of a bull head, maybe amuletic function (1.9x1.4x0.7cm), drilled across between ears and horns. Three rectangles (1.3x0.9x0.3cm), each with two drill holes. Six rectangles with one projection (1.6x1.2x0.3cm), each with two drill holes plus the projection drilled. One rectangle with two opposed projection (1.6x1.3x0.3cm), drilled twice. One projection fragment. Fourty tubular beads, (L: 1.65-0.6cm; D: up to 0.3cm), as well as seven small fragments. Surface badly worn.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by The Petrie Museum of Egyptian Archaeology. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

The beads rectangular in shape, rectangular with one or two protuberances, look like very stylised amulets of offering table. On these types of amulets see Andrews 1994, 92-93, fig. 92f). Andrews, C. 1994. Amulets of Ancient Egypt, Austin.
52 beads in glazed composition: 40 tube (Xia type PN22), 11 rectangular spacer (PN23?), 1 bull head. Xia, N. 2014, Ancient Egyptian Beads, Heidelberg.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (OK.415) (phase 3)
